Posts.Content: Hello I was diagnosed with lobular cancer ER+ In my left breast in February last year. I was never given any doubt that I had cancer from my first appointment. I had an inverted nipple with nothing showing on my mammogram. Wondering what the MRI will find is worrying. There is plenty of time to think about it as the machine whirs. In my case it found 2 other areas of concern, so there were no arguments, it was a mastectomy.  The results after the operation showed that these extras were not cancer, and luckily nodes were ok. So l made a quick recovery- worked at those exercises and accepted the offer of Pilates and I am now on Letrozole for 10 years, so they must be thinking  that I could reach 82! So all the best for the operation. Your mind will be more settled, although life is not quite the same. X
Posts.Title: Waiting for MRI invasive lobular cancer ER+

Posts.Content: Morning No one asked about my knickers, but I was wearing a sparkling white new pair for the occasion! Had a lovely calming chat with nurse as I walked to theatre , stopping off at the toilet on the way. Strange what we worry about, but it takes your mind off the real event! X
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: Starting to feel nostalgic looking at your photos. Loved all these views when l used to visit my mum and sister who lived in Eastbourne. Mum at 100 loved to be taken out for a ride to Beachy Head.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Oh my, l remember this scenario so well. Coat on ready to go for results, then the call - not enough results back. Yes you will think the worst. What have they found? Are they having to consult with someone? They don’t know how to tell me.  One week later l left the hospital with a packet of Letrozole and no further treatment. I have just waited 3 weeks for first year mammogram results. You’d think we wouid know what to expect bot this worrying keeps coming back. Best Wishes for your results.
Posts.Title: Results day tomorrow - both hopeful and terrifirf

Posts.Content: I had a mastectomy on March 23. The physio thought my seroma might need draining but the breast nurse said it looked normal for 3 weeks after surgery and then said it would go but could take a few months. At least I know! Just one small patch is sore , it looks like a minature volcano . My scar has also healed well, so we are all in the same boat ( floating in fluid) !Sorry !
Posts.Title: Seroma update

Posts.Content: Hello fellow crafters. Now this is a thread I can relate too. I knitted away after my mastectomy. Had a new grandchild on the way. Then I moved on to knitted knockers and crochet.  Luckily these distractions keep us sane and off the wine. ! Very impressed with everyone’s efforts and will add my pram blanket and toy. l am a Woolwarehouse fan too. Love those bags they send the yarn in. l am waiting for knee replacements so plenty of knitting this year too. xx
